physDesc.p: This letter is six pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: Mr/ Greenslet has told me of your letter to him of June 19th. I do not know what he answered himself, but I think I can straighten out the matter by writing to you.

Let me hastily say that Mr. Greenslet had nothing whatever to do with the preface. The book was handed to him for publication with the preface all written, and he accepted it, preface and all. No one of us six were responsible for that preface. It was tinkered by all six of us, and no one of us would be at liberty to change it without the concurrence of all the others.

Now I think, my Dear Girl, you are laboring under a misapprehension in the attitude you take in requesting that “Poetry” should be mentioned in the bibliography at the end of our book. You are taking the attitude that “Poetry” is a book in itself. Now I never understood that you so understood it. You call it a magazine of verse; it comes out serially like a magazine; and in
treating it as a magazine, rather than as a book, no slight was intended to you. We were merely following the usual method in such cases. If 30 pages out of 77 were first printed in your paper, that still leaves 47 unaccounted for. Of those 47, a good many appeared in “Poetry and Drama”, “The Egoist,” and “The Smart Set.” In those cases, therefore, the copyrights were held by them. No one of them has made any kick.

It is, of course, true that you were the great herald of Imagism in this country, but our preface was not supposed to contain a history of Imagism; and we only made the remark about the first Anthology which we did, to explain why we were publishing under a separate title. I thought it abominable the way Ezra left out all acknowledgement of “Poetry” in his first Anthology; but in acknowledging out debt to “Poetry” in the usual way, I felt that we had done all that was necessary in that particular place, and I think that, treating your book as a magazine, we did all that was customary.

I have never heard of a magazine refusing permission to authors, or a group of authors, to
reprint any of their poems which had appeared in its pages. It is a commonplace of the business. Many magazines merely go so far as to say that in buying and copywriting the poem, they are only buying the magazine rights. This is the attitude which “The Atlantic” takes, and even the magazines that do not announce that fact always act upon it.

You know how greatly I admire the work you have done in “Poetry.” Out of my own head, and with no suggestion from you, I have offered to write an article upon it, and you know I shall keep my word. And if I do not succeed in getting it published in “The New Republic” or elsewhere, it will not be for want of trying. But I feel that you are mistaken in feeling slighted in the preface of the Anthology, or in the bibliography. I feel it would be wiser for “Poetry” to assume merely the position desired by all other magazines, and seek its advertising where it legitimately belongs. To desire special recognition in a place where it would have sounded
dragged in, or in a bibliography which was carefully stated to be of books, in contradiction to magazines, would be amateurish, I think. If “Some Imagist Poets” should reach a second edition, I trust you will not feel offended if I, who although not the editor, am responsible for the printing of the book, begged you not to desire us to change the preface, as to do so, when six people must agree to it, is almost an impossibility.

I beg you, dear Harriet, to believe in our sincere appreciation of “Poetry” and our admiration of you as its editor, and leave me to do you all possible justice in the article which I write this Autumn. If you still feel strongly upon the subject, rather than give you a wrong impression as to our gratitude, will you allow me to insert a paragraph to that effect in the new Anthology, which will appear next Spring, rather than to laboriously change the plates of this one? The latter I will certainly do. In fact, I think I should have done it anyway, but I shall be very much obliged to you, if you will not insist upon any change in this one, simply because of mechanical difficulties, of distance from the other authors and electrotype plates, to mak
ing a change.

Now it is my turn to kick. It seems to me that in your review you were a little unkind to us. You laid a great deal of stress upon the fact that we did not acknowledge our debt to you. You referred constantly to the people who are not in the Anthology. Would it have been disloyal to Ezra, and would not it have been graceful to me, had you confined your remarks to the things which were in the book and ont referred to so many of the things which were not? It seems to me that my constant loyalty to you, my sincere interest in this magazine, and my desire to always identify myself with it as much as possible, might have led you to assume the dignified attitude of silence, which we have taken in regard to our schism with Ezra. If I chose to come out with the whole story, Ezra would not be left in a very pleasant position. I am willing to be absolutely silent and not accuse him in any way; but I do not like being covertly accused, particularly by those whom I consider (sic) my friends, and who I think
owe me the same loyalty which I always show to them. How loyal I am to you, Harriet, you will never know. I wrote and remonstrated with Richard for his method of reviewing your book and, although I am not my brother’s keeper, I have done my best. Don’t you want to cease referring to the break between Ezra and the rest of us? If I am willing to be silent, you, as Ezra’s friend, should be thankful.
div.postscript: P.S. Ferris Greenslet tells me that a magazine editor only buys the magazine copyright to to poems he publishes, not the book copyright, unless it is specifically so stated in the contract. He says that it has been tried in court over and over again, and this is always the decision.
